div.p:
A Compendious description of the principal Places of
Trade on the West Coast of Africa commonly called Guinea
commencing at the River Senegal, the northern boundry and
ending at the Bay of Ambriz on the Coast of the Congo boundry,
comprehending a space of near six hundred fifty Leagues of Sea
Coast with a brief Account of the Productions and Artices Articles of Trade.

The great River Sanhaga, or Senegal, called by the
Natives Notes
Senegal.
B-Fing ; i.e.
Black-River
but this is not the
great River NigerBa-Fing; enters in the Atlantic Ocean under the Sixteenth
Degree of North Latitude and is the North Limit of Guinea, as
it divides that Country from Morocco; On the north Shore of this
River we find the Moors of Barbary, yellow Ugly Race of
People. And on the South side we find only Negroes, the black
est and handsomest in the World.+The Moors do not
intermarry with Negroes; This
Nation of Blacks are
called Yolofs.

This River is navigable fifty or Sixty Leagues for
Vessels of Eight or Ten Feet Water, and three hundred Leagues
for flat Embarcations, in the Time of the Rains: But having
a Bar This Bar requires
a good practical Pilotof Sand before its Mouth on which there are only seven
or eight Feet Water in the Dry Season and on which there
is almost always a tremendeous Surf, it is one of the most
dangerous to pass of any Bar in the known World: Not a year
passes without the loss of Vessels and Boats with their Crews.

a Gum Senega is an
aqueous Gum and its
principal use is in
the fabrication of Silks The Staple Commodity of this Place is the Gum Senega,
a little fine Gold, some ordinary Ivory and about Seven or
Eight hundred Slaves of both Sexes annually.

b All the East India and
other Goods carried
thither must be of the
first quality: The amber
(That is to say) only
semitransparent, or
to look like Fallow
half hot & half cold, as
it cools when Melted:
The Corral must be fire,
and the Pipes or Beads
large & thick.The Merchandize carried thither for Sale consist of
the finest East India Basts, English and Flemish Fowling-Pieces,
Fusils, Sabres and Guns, Powder with Musquet Ball Drop Shott,
Lead Barrs & fine Gunflints: Scarlet broad Cloths, and Blue Ditto,
Red Baize, Blue Ditto; French or Counterfeit Bretagna
Linnens, Dimitty or British Muslinets; Amber Beads, Red
Corral, fine Beads from Leghorn & Venice, French or Spanish Brandy,
Dollars in Specie. All these are for the use of the Black People.
But besides, Bardeaux-Mine, Fine Flour, White Sugar, Coffee
and Spices, good Linnens &.ca et cetera for the White Merchants; and above
all, The Spices called Cloves which are in general demand, as
well for foods as, to String on the Women's Necklaces, by way of
Perfume.

The dry Season begins in October and ends in May;
The Rainy Season ,
commences in June ,
and finishes in September.

Notes:
Goree Island
about two Miles from
the Main Land
a deep Channel between
them.The Island of Goree is scituated about six Leagues
Eaest East South-East from Cape Verd, and opposite to Cape Bernardo, is
only a quarter of a League in length, and of a Triangular form; The
South Point terminates in a high Hill, the North Point is low, where
the Fort and Vilage stands: This Island is composed of Rocks &
is almost destitue destitute of Verdure and Water, except in the Rains.

The Road of Shipping is very spacious and has
good anchorge anchorage ; four or five hundred Slaves, (chiefly Yolofs ,
) may
be collected here in a Year: And the Merchandize assorted for this
Market, may consist of the same kinds and qualitites, as at Senegal.
The Prices of Negroes at both Places, from one hundred to one hun
dred and fifty Dollars pr per head: The Seasons like those of the former.

Gambia River,
one of the Noblest
in the whole WorldThe River of Gambia is the finest in all Africa
being navigable for three hundred Leagues for Vessels of two hundred
Tons: This Country produces Millet, Cattle, Bees-Wax & Fruits
in abundance; but is unhealthy from the low Marshy lands
on each Side; About two thousand Slaves may be purchased in this
River in Twelve Months, composed of various Nations, such as
Yolofs, Bambarrais, Woolis, Serrawoolis, Fulas, Mandingos
and Floops: The Assortment of Merchandize ,
& Prices of these Slaves,
are nearly similar to those of Senegal, but somewhat cheaper.

The Yolofs were described at Senegal, as the most
Beautiful Negroes in the World, especially the Females: but being
of an intrepid haughty Character, they are not fit for Field labour,
although they make good Tradesmen and house Servants.

The Bambarra's Bambarras are the tallest & strongest People
in Guinea, very fit for low Marshy Lands ,
& Sugar Plantations.

The Woolies, and Serrawoolies ,
are of moderate
Stature, and appear as a medium between the Yolofs & Bambarras.

The Fulas, and Floops ,
are proper for the care of
Cattle in general, and many Fulas make good Plantation Servants.

x
All the nations mentioned
here as produced in Gambi i
a
are called Mandingas
at the Havana.The Mandingas are good Herdsmen .
& Cultivators,
being sober cleanly and honest.

This River being so easy of navigation, so extensive -
so easy of Ingress, and Egress, and so abundant of Provisions; is
too much frequented by Europeans and Americans, who are
induced by these advantages, to go into it in preference to other Places:
The facility of the Passage, from hence and from Senegal & Goree, to the
American Islands, is also a powerful Motive: The Navigation
being often performed in Eighteen or Twenty Days.

The Isles Delos ( Los Las Islas de los Idolos) These are
five in number, in Latitude nine Degrees and from sixteen to twenty
Minutes North: The Road for Vessels of any burthenies say great ships between the
most easterly of the five, and a Point called Tumbo; which is oftentimes
taken for a Promontory of the Main Land; but which is also an Island.

This easternmost of the five Islands is called in the
Charts ,
Factor Isle, by reason of its having been always adopted
for European Settlements, or Factories, from its convent Springs
of fresh Waters, safe Anchorage, and facility of entrance at either
the North, or the South Ends, as may be seen in the British Chart
of this Coast. There are other good Anchoring Places also among
these Islands noted in said Charts. Note:
o
See the Chart of this Coast
published in London
in 1794 and other new
Editions revised and
many new additions
made, by Navigators:
Sold by Laurie & Whittle
Strand, London.

These Islands afford an Assylum, secure from
any sudden invasion of the neighbouring Negroes, being at a
sufficient distance from the nearest part of the Continent, to
prevent a surprize. Dry, healthy Soil, with good scituations for
habitation Stores &.ca et cetera and safe harbour, for small Embarcations,
with abundance of excellent Fish easily caught.

The Scituation of the Isles Delos is unaparraleled
on the Coast of Africa. Being nearly equidistant from & between the
Mouths of Rio Grande * See the same Chart
with the latest improuve
ments published by
Laurie & Whittle
London to the Northwest, and Sherbro to the South East
an extent of upwards of Sixty Leagues of Sea boast; all the inter
mediate Space being intersected, with more than twelve navigable
Rivers, abounding with Fish, Rice & Slaves; of which last
article, from two thousand ,
to two thousand five hundred, may
be collected every Year; with a sufficient quantity of Rice, to
maintain them while in Africa, and in their Voyage to the
American Islands.

Note.
Between the River Gambia
and the Isles Delos no
good Places of Trade for
Ships is to be found but
what are established
by the Portuguese; But
there are a great num
ber of small Rivers &
Islands where the
British Traders send
small Vessels to purchase
Slaves, Rice, Elephants
Teeths and Salt.The Price of these Slaves in time peace is from One
hundred to one hundred and twenty Dollars; and in War with between the
British united Kingdoms, and France from sixty to eighty Dollars
in Merchandize properly assorted, consisting of a great variety
of East India and Manchester Cotton Cloths, of divers patterns
and qualities: Fusils, Fowling Pieces, Sabres, Pistols &.ca et cetera Gun
Powder, Musquet Ball, Drop Shott, Lead in Bars, Iron in ditto,
Brass Pans, Kettles, Tobacco, Brandy, Beads, Silks &.ca et cetera.

Also, All kinds of Provision, and necesaries for the
use of the Europeans settled in the Rivers on this Coast. who
having the same inducements to establish themselves here,
as others before mentioned have found in Gambia, are to be
found still more numerous; consequently a greater concur
ence in Trade ,
exists in these Countries, than in any in Africa.

Notes
Sierraleone.
These Mountains are
a Prodigeous Mass
of Volcanic Matter
thrown into various
Ridges like an assem
blage of what are cal
led Sierras in Spanish,
& consist of from three
to five Stages or heigthts heights
one above another into
the Clouds with many
Parks, & Grotesque
Shapes of the most
fanciful & romantic
appearance & covered
with Noble Trees.
from which, Landscapes
worthy the Pencil of
Salvator Rosa
might be taken.The River of Sierraleone is the next considerable
Place of Trade as we continue to proceed towards the South
Cap, Sierraleone being the North West Point of the very high
Ridge of Mountains of the name in the Margin: These Moun
tains form a Peninsula joined to the Mainland by a very low
Isthmus almost divided by Bunch River on the North and
Kates River on the South So that at a distance of seven or
eight Leagues at Sea, These Sierras appear as an Island &
may be seen in clear Weather twenty five Leagues.

As we do not profess to give any directions for
entering any of the African Rivers, or Ports, in this Work, we
refer to the British Charts of this Coast already mentioned which
we trust will be found sufficiently exact and particular, for
the purposes of Navigating generally. And where a pratical practical
Pilot is necessary, it will be noted in the Margin.

The entrance of this River is deep enough for the
largest first Rate Ships of War and is in Latitude eight Degrees
& thirty Minutes North. The Produce is Rice, Camwood & Slaves
of the Timanny, Mandinga & Bulam Nations, all excellent,
and of which One thousand may be collected annully annually , and as the
River Scarcies to the North, and the Bannas Bannanas IslandsThe Bannanas are
three high and very
beautiful fruitful
Islands ten Leagues
Southerly from Sierra
leone, & the
River Sherbro to the South, with all its branches, may be
considered as Appendages to Sierraleone we may alow about
five hundred more to be brought from these Places, as also
two hundred Tons of Rice from the whole of this District.

One hundred Tons of CamwoodCamwood is of a
rich Orange Colour
very compact & used
by Dyers. Value in
England forty Guineas
pr per Ton .
& which costs
here the Value of a
Prime Slave. might also be
bought yearly. But the British having formed a Settlement
on the South Side of Sierraleone River and claiming a right to
the Coast to a considerable Extent Southward which being bought
from the Natives & paid for by the English Nation. Other Nations
may find it inconvent inconvenient to attempt establishments within these limits.

The Assortment of Merchandize proper for these
parts are nearly the same as at the Isles Delos with the
additions of more Bars of Iron, Tobacco, Brass, Kettles & Pans
and a large kind of Flat Brass Pans called Neptunes for the
purpose of making Salt (which abounds on the Coast near Sherbro)
and rederring rendering the quantities of Cotton & of Linnen Cloths propor
tionally.

There are many Europeans settled all along
this Coast which causes much opposition in Trade.

The Rains begin in June & end in October .
from
that Month to Christmas, Tornados prevail. Jan.y January ,
Feb.y February & March are
dry Months. April and May, Tornados again.

Cabe Corso.
Annamaboo,
Whyda or Juda,
Mina &.ca et cetera
European Establishm.t Establishment We have hither to been treating of the Windward Coast of Guinea
and are approaching towards the Gold-Coast which we will pass
over in a cursory manner, because the British having Forts and Castles
at all the Places worth mentioning no other Nations may be admit
to Trade there except a few Hollanders and Portuguese. The Negroes
brought from thence to the Havana are the best in Guinea & called
Minas. This Coast produces more than two thousand Slaves annually,
some fine Gold & Maize.

The next in order as we proceed Eastward for the Gulf of Biafra
and the Rivers Lagos ,
and Benin, or Formosa; and also Cape Formoso,
all this Coast is inhospitable and very little frequented being for the
most part drowned occasionally by the Sea or by the heavy Rains
in August and September. Best not withstanding all these diffi
culties. As there are very good Slaves to be had at equitable Prices.
The hardy and persevering Spirit of the British, the French, and
some Portuguese, have surmounted these Obstacles and carried on
a Traffic for Negroes, Ivory and Cotton Cloths similar to the Cloths
made in the Cape de Verd Islands. But it is not advisable to at
tempt the establishement of Factories on this Part of the Coast.

New Calebar and
Bonny Rivers,
Independent KingsFrom Cape Formoso, still advancing Eastward we pass by the
Mouths of Six Rivers of little Note and the Seventh ispening is the Bar
called Bonny Bar which is the common entrance of the River called
New Calebar, and Bonny, but which are in fact two seperate and
very large Rivers running far into the Country, producing Yams,
Ivory, Palm Oil .
and abundance of Slaves in numbers superior to
any Place in Guinea. These Negroes are called at the Havana Calebaris.

River Lagos
Benin & Cape
Formoso &.ca et cetera
Independent Negro
Kings & PrincesThe Assortment of Merchandize adapted to these
Rivers is composed of East India & Manchester Goods, Gun-Powder, Arms
Brandy, Hardware, Beads, Silk, handkerchiefs & a variety of other Articles
amounting to eighty Dollars pr per head a little more or less, besides what may
be expended in the purchase of Yams Plantains &.ca et cetera for the Food of the
Slaves while on the Coast and the Passage to America.

We have mentioned New Calebar before Bonny because the
former comes next in place before Bonny, but ,
The latter is of much
greater importance producing a very superior number of Slaves and
those of better Constitutions and Temperaments. Perhaps we cannot
find any Place of Trade in Guinea to compare with this for numbers
produced Annually if not Malemba on the Cacongo Coast. But, if
Malemba fails in this degree of comparison, it enjoys advantages
superior in other aspects being healthier, more facil of access &
departure together with a favorable Climate & Wind to America.

Rivers Del Rey
and
Old CalebarContinuing our Route Eastward to the bottom of the Gulf of
Guinea or Biafra we come to the River Del Rey and Old Calebar ,
the first of these of little Frequentation, but ,
the latter of some consequence
for its Trade which consists of Ivory, Palm Oil, Red Wood for Dyeing,
Ebony and Slaves of inferior quality but cost litte. The Assortment
for their purchase being of coarser & cheaper.

River CamaronesFrom Old Calebar the Coast bends more Southerly to the River
Camaroons, which produces much good Ivory and a few bad Slaves.

Rivers Danger and
GabonThe Coast streches Southerly to the Rivers Danger and Gabon.
This last is a very fine River, navigable many Leagues into the interior
of the Country producing Ivory, Ebony, Red Wood & Some Slaves and
is scituated nearly under the Equinoctial Line & here the Slaves are
of the most feeble, effeminate & cowardly Characters, the worst confor
mation of Bodies & Limbs in all Guinea and are bought cheap accordingly.
Bad Slaves
are of no valueBut be it remarked and remembered (once for always) That to
Purchase a Slave such as we have just described because it costs
Little, is a proof of ignorance, covetousness, Avarice & folly, all which
Vices are sure to be punished in the Purchaser by the Weakness of
the Slave and inability of sensing his Master if per chance, he has
the Will to do it, and which scarcely ever happens for such cowards
are always mischievous, Lazy & Tracherous.

The Islands St. Thomas
Princes and Fernand
depo very plentiful
of ProvisionsFrom Gabon to Cape López Gonsalvez the Coast runs South with
some Rivers and Islands on the intervening Space of no note for Trade.
But we have the Islands of Fernandepo, Princes and Saint Thomas
in the Bosom of this African Gulf and in a manner centrically
opposite most of the principal Ports, which Islands being cultivated
aford plentiful refreshment and great relief to the exhausted Slaves
and Mariners after their fatigues of the Coast and their tedious
navigation towards these Hospitable Retreats against contrary Winds
and Currents which constantly prevail. this immense Bay being the
Receptacle of the Napours brought hither from Angola by the South East
Trade Wind from Angola & Congo.

Cape López Gonsalvez
First Promontory
of the Southern
Atlantic Ocean
East side thereof.Cape López & Gonsalvez in nearly one Degree South Latt.d Latitude is the
terminating Point of the South side of the Gulf of Biafara which we
have traced in its inflexions from Cape Formosa ,
and from this
Primary Promontory of the East Coast of the Southern Atlantic Ocean,
the Coasts of Yumba, Loanga, Cacongo, Sonhio, Congo and Angola &.a et cetera
follow in succession towards the South: But in common discourse
all these Countries are collectively called Angola by Europeans .
& Congo
in the Havana &.ca et cetera .

As we recede from the Equinoctial Line to the North the Natives
of the respective Countries are more Robust, laborious and of Superior
Understanding; And, in like Manner as we proceed towards the South
General remarks
on the Persons, the
Genius & Character
of the Negroes born
near the Equator.we experience the same gradations of Conformation, Beauty & Intelligence.
We will not give the difference of Latitude all the merit of this Physical
approach towards perfections, because although the Rule may hold good in
the Conformation and external appearance of Persons until the Sixteeth
Degree of North Latitude. Yet we know to a certainty the Intellectual and
Moral facutlties arrise at their Zenith in more temperate Climes.

And if we go on to the Southern Promontory we find Hottentots at the
Cape of Good Hope, the most Stupid Race on the Globe except the Laplanders
from hence we conclude that the Soil has much influence on the Physical
as well as the Intellectual Character. We are led into this Digression
by comparing the Africans born on the North and on the South of the Equator
and within the Space of five or six degrees of Latitude on each side of
it. Those of the neighbourhood of that Line on both sides inhabit low
Marshy Lands and live upon Fish and Moist Roots, such as Yams &.a et cetera .
Their being obliged to made through Mud and Roots of Trees gives that then very
awkward & Shambling-Gait which is so dissagreable and really causes
that slow & Lazy walk we often remark in New Negroes.

As the Writer is professedly treating of the Negro Species, he thinks
(as they are become an Article of Commerce.) it is his duty, to point out
where to purchase the best, and to avoid and refrain from the Worst.

The first Place of Trade we arrive at after quitting the Gulf of
Mayumba Bay.Biafara and progressing Southerly agreeably to our general Plan,
is the Bay of Mayumba in the Province of Yumba and Empire
of Loanga. This is a Spacious Bay insufficiently described in the Chart
of this Coast published in London By Laurie &Whittle
in 1792 . And is the only Place in Africa where
the Red-Wood for Dyers use, called Bar-Wood, is to be had in quan
tities sufficient for Lading Ships of great Burthen. It seems to be
inexhaustible in this Neighbourhood: furnishing more than one
thousand Tons annually for the last Fifty Years past to the Writer's own
Personal knowledge. He having been at the Place in the Year 1759
assisting in the purchase and reception of four hundred Tons of that
Article and concerned in its conduction to Holland several Years anterior.

Besides the Bar-Wood, much Ivory is to be found. Also about
three hundred and fifty or four hundred Slaves may be bought reasonably
but these Negroes are rather inferior to those at Malemba on this Coast
Upon the whole the Bar-Wood and Ivory are the Staple Articles of
Mayumba. Yet if a Vessel follows what is called the Short Route
to Malemba or the River Congo, The South South East Trade Wind, with
the Current setting almost continually to the North North West and into
the Gulf of Biafara, will oblige her to pass in front of this Bay. And

Cape Mount is a very high Promontory
Cabo del Mônte
Independent Chiefsconsisting of one single Elevation which may be seen seventeen
or eighteen Leagues and as the Land is low 0 level to a considerable
distance to the North West and South East of it, this Cape appears
to be an Island when seen at eight or nine Leagues from the
offing at Sea: and lies in Six Degrees and forty Minutes North
Latitude. The Road for Shipping is on the north side of this
Mountain about one Mile from it and opposite a small River
the Mouth of which is eastward from the Anchorage.

Cabo Montserrado
Independent
NegroesCape Mesurada lies about eighteen Leagues
South East of Cape Mount, is very high and very like the
latter except that is more cut and divided on its Summit having
somewhat the appearance of the Crest of a Cock. The Road for
Vessels is also in its North Side opposite the River St. Paul
and is nearly similar in all thing to Cape Mount.

Baxa,
or Rio San Juan
also Negro chiefsBassa about sixteen or seventeen Leagues to the
South East of Mesurada is a Bay very Spacious, good Anchorage
Fresh Water & Fire Wood easily produced. This is a good Station for a
Factory Ship being the best and safest Road on his Coast.

General Remarks
relative to the Windward
Coast of GuineaCape Mount, Mesurada ,
& Bassa are the
principal and only Places of Trade for large Ships on this part of
the Coast. although there are many smaller Places and some Rivers
which afford their share d s . These are, The Rivers Gallinas, Mana
Junk, Little Bassa, River of Young Sesters, Little Sesters and
Grand River Sesters as maybe seen in the Chart before mentioned
and this Coast is called Lua Lua, a Name which maybe traced
easily to its origin from the frequented and notable repetition of
those Words in the Speech of the Natives, who are collectively
called Gang ,
Gas, at the Havana.

Two Thousand good Slaves may be had yearly
from the above named Places; by means of One Factory Ship at
Cape Mount, and another at Bassa. And as all this Country
abounds in Rice of excellent quality: a sufficient quantity of
that indispensible Article for the maintanance of all these Slaves
whilst remaining on the Coast and daring their Passage to
the American Islands can be procured.

The Assortment of Goods for this Coast is made
up of East India & Manchester Cottons, some French or Counterfeit
Bretagnas, Much Rum, Tobacco, Fusils of various sorts, Sabres, Iron
in Bars, Hardware, Hats, Beads, Gun Powder in small Kegs or
Barrels, Dutch Knives, Lead in Bars, Musquet Bale, Drop Shott &.ca et cetera .

And while she may be obliged to wait for a favourable Opportunity of
proceeding to the Southward in her way towards Loanga. Malemba,
Congo &.ca et cetera , She may occasionally purchase forty or fifty Slaves: and
as many Elephants Teeth at low Prices; These Elephants Teeth as
also the Strong Fusts of Hair growing at the Ends of their Tails are
in such demand at Malemba that extravant extravagant Prices are paid for them.
The Elephants Teeth thus dearly purchased are planted in the Ground in the
burial Places of the Grand Personages whose memory is honored and
their Hairs are held in esteem in a greater or less degree in proportion
to the Size of the Tooth planted at the Head of their deseased Ancestors.

The Hairs of the Elephants Tails, are worn round the Neck
in Rings of a single Hair, few or None, but Princes and Nobles are seen with them.

LoangaThe Bay of Loanga is the next Place of Commerce to the South
of Mayumba being very extensive but rather Shallow although many
Ships may ride in it in twenty four Feet Water. As this Bay is not
well sheltered by its Southern Point from whence the Wind common
ly blows and from which quarter but obliquely from the Offing the
Swell of the Sea comes, it happens frequently that at the Full and
Change of the Moon. There heaves a very great and forcible Body
of rolling Waves into this Bay which break on the Beach in a trem
menduous Surf, and occasion so much agitation of the Ships at
Anchor as to menace the rupture of their Cables, or the striking of
the Ships on the bottom. These Remarks
are made here
because they are
not Extant elsewhere,
The Writer has been
twice at Loanga,
and the first time,
travelled by Land.
on foot, from near
Mayumba thither

Bovali is the Capital and Residence of the
Emperor and is a large Town about two Leagues in the Country, here
all the Trade is generally carried on, and Factories kept, by those who
go to this Place to purchase Negroes & Elephants Teeth, although,
sometimes the Court grants the privilege of erecting them near the
Beach: But as the situations near the Sea, are unhealthy, it is
more adviseable to fix the Magazines at Booali.

Two thousand Slaves may be had here in one Year
and purchased with East India, Manchester or Rouen Manufactur Manufacture
of Cottons &.c et cetera , Arms either Flemmish or English, French, British
or Dutch Brandy, British Earthen Ware, Gun Powder, a few Beads
some good Cornal Drop Shott for the Chase, Knives & hardware &.ca et cetera .

We ought not to quit these remarks without mention
ing the Charracter of the Natives, whether Freemen or Slaves, They are
bold, enterprizing, treacherous, drunken and lazy. and it is here that
those Slaves are sold which are called at the Havana. the Congo
Mundungas, and Cost at this Place about Sixty or Seventy Dollars.

Malemba.
Called by the Natives
Tula Chimfuca
Lacacongo.Proceeding Southwards from Loanga and prasing before
the Mouth of the River Cacongo which divides the Empire of
Loanaga from the Kingdom of Cacongo of which the Point called
Malemba is the Plan of Trafic; w W e find a fine healthy elevated
Plain where there is a Town with a Governor and other public
Officers establish for the preservation of good Order and distribution
of Justice, with moderaton and equity. Such is Malemba where
Factories are erected near enough to the Coast and in sight of the
Ships, and where all the Slaves are bought with Merchandize
similar to that mentioned at Loanga, and being of better quality
they may cost ten Dollars pr per head more.

Malemba is the principal Place of Trade on
all this Coast although it has no Port and only a small Bay for
landing in Boats. The Ships ride at Anchor at a considerable
distance from the Shore on the open Coast, but as the Climate
is mild and Storms very rare there is little or no danger.

Four or Five Thousand good Slaves are sold here
annually for Goods as above mentioned: Water and Fire-Wood
are plentiful, but neither at this Place nor any other on this Coast
are any Provisions to be had for their maintainance on their
passage to America or even whilst remaining here except a few
Cakes made from the Yucca, called here Canki.

The Government is kind to Strangers, affording them
protection and redress of grievances gratis. The Populace are
good humoured, obliging, and free from the Vices of Rancour & Revenge
but the Shades in their Character, are drunkenness, laziness and a
great degree of Salaciousness amongst the Females.

Upon the whole, Malemba may fairly vie with
Banny or any other Place in Guinea for Trade .
& is Superior in
respect to Suavity of Climate: The South-East Trade-Wind which
prevail on this Coast secures an easy transit to the American
Islands and makes the Navigation pleasant.

CabindaCabinda a few Leagues Southerly by from Malemba
has a fine commodious Bay and safe Anchorage with plenty of Fire
Wood and Fresh Water, where Ships may lie in better security than
any other Place on this Coast, and where about fifteen hundred
good Slaves may be produced yearly much in the same manner & Price
as at Malemba. Cabinda being so commodious it may be asked
why it is not superior in Trade? The Answer is, That this superiority
is derived from the free intercourse with the internal Countries

Congo, or the River Zaire, discharges a prodigious
quantity of Fresh Water into the Southern Atlantic Ocean with a
most impetuous Current, carrying with it floating Islands composed
of matted Roots, Reeds, Earth, Grass & some with Trees to eighty
or one hundred Leagues from its Mouth. The navigation into this River

But the British African Association have by the Perseverance and
indefatigable Industry of their Traveller Mungo Park Esquire a
Scotch Gentleman well known and Credited; discovered the Head
and a great Part of the Course of that Famous River on which he
actually navigated as far as Silla beyond the City of Sego, the Capital
of the powerful Kingdom of Bambarra. And from good information
corroborated by various undoubted facts & proofs he found that the Niger
continued its Course Easterly to Tumbuctoo, and from then Southerly
passing by Houssan a very large & populous City. But no knowledge
of the remainder of this vast collection of African Waters can be had
with certainty. Reflecting on the necessity of some outlet for
these prodigious Stream, and on the Deluge poured on the Face of
the Earth between the Tropics every Year in the Rainy Seasons; Also
taking Cursory view of the quantity if fresh Water discharged by
the Nile, Senegal, Gambia and other Rivers in Africa now all
or most of them traced up to their Sources, or nearly so: taking also
Mosambique into the Account, we find none of them to throw
out a quantity of Water equal to that sent forth by the Rivers Congo,
Nor if we were to add the quantities dicharged by many of them
together it would not amount in the Agregate of to a quantity equal to this immense Drain
of South Guinea.

Considering al the foregoing Circumstances and
many more too tedious to be inserted here, We venture to hazard
an Opinion that the Congo is the Mouth of the Niger.

There remains now only one Independent Place of Trade

This is an inconsiderable Place in Latitude Seven Degrees
and fifty One Minutes South only visited by a few small Vessells,
the Slaves bought here are of much the same qualities as at Malemba
& somewhat cheaper, but they bring many small Slaves to Market
who are too Young to put to Work.
